questions.text: A young child with absent thymus is brought to the OPD with features of hypoparathyroidism and tetany. Which of the following marked area in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

The patient most certainly has DiGeorge syndrome based on the clinical history and the imaging, which displays pharyngeal pouches (thymic and parathyroid defects). It might be brought on by faulty third- and fourth-pharyngeal-pocket development. The thymus' absence is expressly stated in the provided stem. Hence, choice 12 is the better of the two.

 

  • DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy that is caused by hemizygous interstitial deletion of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects, including conotruncal defects, hypoparathyroidism, and dysmorphic syndrome. Microdeletion at chromosome 22q11 can lead to variable presentations including -
  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypocalcemia 2° to parathyroid aplasia.

          (Mnemonic: CATCH-22)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 : External Auditory Meatus. The first pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the middle ear cavity, eustachian tube, and external auditory meatus. These structures are primarily involved in auditory functions and do not relate to the endocrine or immune system anomalies seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option B. 10: Palatine Tonsil. The second pharyngeal pouch develops into the palatine tonsils. While DiGeorge syndrome can include a range of pharyngeal derivatives issues, the palatine tonsil is not typically affected in ways that lead to the major clinical symptoms of thymus and parathyroid gland absence.

 

Option D. 14: Ultimobranchial Body. This derivative of the fourth pharyngeal pouch contributes to the development of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid, which are responsible for calcitonin production. Although related to calcium metabolism, its involvement is distinct from the parathyroid gland's role in calcium homeostasis and does not directly relate to the primary symptoms of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The most relevant site of defect in DiGeorge syndrome, given the symptoms described (absent thymus, hypoparathyroidism, and tetany), is associated with abnormalities in the third pharyngeal pouch—specifically the development of the inferior parathyroid glands and the thymus

questions.text: A newborn presents with the condition shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital anomaly where the bladder is exposed outside the body. It presents as a defect in the lower abdominal wall, with the bladder mucosa visible. Characteristic features include a bifid scrotum, abnormal genitalia (bifid penis or clitoris), and exposure of the bladder trigone. The condition is often associated with other malformations, such as a wide pubic symphysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical hernia: This condition involves protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect at the umbilicus but remains covered by skin. It does not expose the bladder.

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: This defect occurs lateral to the umbilicus, commonly on the right, with the intestines protruding outside the abdomen without a protective membrane. The defect does not involve the bladder.

 

Option D. Omphalocele: This condition is characterized by herniation of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a thin membrane. Unlike bladder exstrophy, the organs are covered, and the defect involves the umbilical ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition where the bladder is exposed outside the abdomen, often accompanied by genital and pelvic abnormalities.

questions.text: Calculate the kappa statistics for the given dataset while comparing the IGRA and Mantoux test. [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 0.4

 

 

The kappa statistic is frequently used to test interrater reliability.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The kappa statistic measures the agreement between two tests beyond chance.
  • In this case, the kappa statistic is 0.4, indicating moderate agreement between the IGRA and Mantoux tests.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Does not provide multiple doses
﻿﻿﻿Drug deposition in the oropharynx

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Drug deposition in the oropharynx

 

The given image shows a metered-dose inhaler (MDI). It is a common device used for delivering drugs (like inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators etc.) used in the management of bronchial asthma and COPD.

 

Drug Deposition in the Oropharynx is a well-recognized limitation of MDIs. A significant proportion of the medication can deposit in the oropharynx and upper airways instead of reaching the lower respiratory tract where it is needed. This not only reduces the efficiency of the drug delivery to the lungs but can also increase the risk of local side effects, such as oral thrush when using corticosteroid inhalers.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Bacterial Contamination: While good hygiene is important in the maintenance of any inhaler device, bacterial contamination is not a commonly cited primary drawback of MDIs. Regular cleaning can typically manage this risk.

 

Options B. Does Not Provide Multiple Doses: This is not accurate. MDIs are designed to provide multiple doses. They contain a pressurized canister that delivers a specific dose of medication in aerosol form with each actuation.

 

Options D. Not Portable: MDIs are actually very portable and convenient, which is one of their advantages. They are compact and easy to carry, making them suitable for use on the go.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common drawback of metered-dose inhalers (MDIs) is drug deposition in the oropharynx, which reduces the efficiency of drug delivery to the lungs and can increase the risk of local side effects.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody

 

History is suggestive of chronic diarrhea with malabsorption occurring at the proximal small intestine (duodenum+ jejunum) causing protein loss (ascites, weight loss diarrhea), Osteoporosis (calcium, magnesium), and Iron deficiency (anemia).

 

All above in a young patient should hint towards the possibility of celiac disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TSH levels: While important for evaluating thyroid function, symptoms of hypothyroidism can overlap with some celiac disease symptoms (like fatigue), but the gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies strongly point towards a primary gastrointestinal cause.

 

Option B. C-peptide levels: C-peptide tests are used to evaluate insulin production levels and are more relevant in the context of diabetes management, not indicated here.

 

Option C. Urine sugar and ketone: This test is used to diagnose and manage diabetes by detecting sugar and ketones in urine, not related to the suspected diagnosis of celiac disease based on the provided symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient presenting with symptoms consistent with malabsorption, including gastrointestinal symptoms and specific nutrient deficiencies like iron and calcium, testing for celiac disease with an IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test should be considered as a critical diagnostic step. This helps in confirming the diagnosis and facilitating appropriate dietary and medical management.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Celiac disease/Chapter 325

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

 

Direct contact with infected animal is not a known mode of transmission for abdominal TB. Tuberculosis is primarily transmitted via inhalation of airborne droplets from a person with active pulmonary TB. While ingestion of Mycobacterium bovis from unpasteurized milk can lead to abdominal TB, Making it a feco-oral route of spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes: This occurs when TB bacteria spread directly from the mesenteric lymph nodes to the intestines. This form of spread is relatively common in abdominal TB.

 

Option C. Feco-oral route: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (from contaminated sputum or unpasteurized milk with M. bovis) can lead to intestinal TB.

 

Option D. Direct contact with infected animal: This is less common but can occur in cases where humans come into contact with animals infected with Mycobacterium bovis, a zoonotic strain of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modes of spread:

 

  1. By ingesting
    1. Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
    2. Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  2. Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  3. Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  4. Through lymphatic channel
  5. Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum

 

Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text: A patient with prosthetic valve implantation, presented after six months with features of endocarditis. What could be the cause? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S. epidermidis

 

Explanation:

 

Endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart, the endocardium, which often involves the heart valves. Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) can be categorized into early-onset and late-onset based on the time of onset after surgery. Early-onset PVE occurs within one year of valve implantation, while late-onset occurs after one year.

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus and is a common cause of early-onset PVE due to its ability to form biofilms on prosthetic materials. Biofilms protect the bacteria from the host immune system and antibiotic treatment, making infections difficult to eradicate.

 

Given that the patient developed endocarditis six months after prosthetic valve implantation, it falls under early-onset PVE. Therefore, the most likely causative organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: While Pseudomonas can cause healthcare-associated infections, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism is a common cause of both native and prosthetic valve endocarditis, particularly in intravenous drug users and hospital-acquired cases. However, for early-onset PVE, Staphylococcus epidermidis is more typical.

 

Option D. S. saprophyticus: This organism is commonly associated with urinary tract infections and is not a typical cause of endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification to diagnose causative organism of Endocarditis -

questions.text: As per the new guidelines of MTP Act, Medical termination of pregnancy can be done after 24 weeks for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foetus malformation

 

Explanation:

 

According to the new guidelines of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, as amended in 2021, medical termination of pregnancy is permitted in India up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Beyond 24 weeks, MTP is permissible in cases where there are documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations. In such cases, the opinion of the state medical board is required to proceed with the termination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rape: This option is incorrect because, while rape or sexual assault is one of the indications for MTP up to 24 weeks, it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Option B. Contraceptive failure: This option is incorrect because contraceptive failure is a social indication for MTP up to 24 weeks, but it is not a specific indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Option D. Insanity: This option is incorrect as it is not mentioned as an indication for MTP beyond 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per the new guidelines of the MTP Act in India, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed beyond 24 weeks of gestation only in cases of documented substantial fetal anomalies or malformations, and the opinion of the state medical board is required.

questions.text: Identify the disorder with X-linked dominant inheritance: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

 

Rett syndrome:

 

 

Other examples of XLD disorders include Vitamin D Independent Rickets, Aicardi Syndrome, Hypophosphatemic Rickets, Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD): Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene and predominantly affects boys, leading to progressive muscle weakness and wasting.

Option C. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, leading to motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.           

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis / Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder most commonly seen in girls, characterized by microcephaly, regression of motor milestones, developmental delay, and stereotyped movements.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for idiopathic thrombocytic purpura? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Splenectomy

 

Splenectomy is considered the best long-term treatment option for patients with chronic ITP who do not respond to medical therapies such as steroids or immunoglobulins. The procedure involves removing the spleen, which is a site of platelet destruction in ITP. Removing the spleen often results in a permanent increase in platelet count, though it is typically reserved for patients who are refractory to first-line treatments.

 

Approach to ITP:

 

If severe ITP @ presentation: Transfusion+ steroids

 

  • Intracranial/GI Bleed
  • PC < 5k
  • Large oral bleed/Retinal bleed

 

Low dose steroids recommended in all cases of ITP.

 

If steroid unresponsive, decision depends on duration:

 

  1. Persistent (3-12 months): Rituximab vs TPO-RA (Romiplostim (S. C.), Eltrombopag (Oral)
  2. Chronic (>12 months): Rituximab vs Splenectomy vs TPO-RA

 

If still persistent/refractory, possible options are:

 

  • Fostamatinib: SyK (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor)
  • MMF/Cyclophosphamide/Azathioprine
  • Autologous stem cell transplant

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV immunoglobulins: Used as a first-line treatment, especially for acute cases of ITP or in severe cases to quickly raise the platelet count, but not as a long-term solution.

 

Option B. Steroids: Common first-line treatment for ITP that can effectively increase platelet count in many patients, though many eventually relapse upon discontinuation or become steroid-dependent.

 

Option D. Blood transfusion: Generally not a primary treatment for ITP since the issue is not the quantity of produced platelets but their premature destruction; transfusions might be used in acute, severe bleeding scenarios but do not address the underlying autoimmune process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is often considered the best treatment option for chronic or refractory idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, particularly when other treatments such as steroids and IV immunoglobulins fail to maintain a safe platelet count or cause side effects that are difficult to manage.

 

Reference: ASH 2021 summary

choices.text: Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

questions.text: Patient presents with acute urinary retention, and suprapubic catheterization is done. Urethrogram show a long segment stricture. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urethral repair with buccal mucosal graft

 

For long urethral strictures, typically those greater than 1-2 cm in length, the preferred management is urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft. This surgical approach involves using a graft from the buccal mucosa (inner cheek lining) to replace or augment the narrowed segment of the urethra, thereby restoring normal urine flow. Buccal mucosal grafts are favored due to their durability, excellent tissue characteristics, and high success rates in reconstructive urology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metal catheter: Using a metal catheter is an outdated approach and is not recommended for managing long urethral strictures due to its potential to cause trauma and worsening of the stricture.

 

Option B. Dilation: Dilation is a temporary and often less effective method for managing urethral strictures, especially long ones. It involves stretching the stricture but does not offer a long-term solution and has a high recurrence rate.

 

Option C. Endoscopic urethrotomy: Endoscopic urethrotomy, also known as visual internal urethrotomy, is typically reserved for short segment strictures (less than 1 cm). It involves using a scope to cut the stricture internally. It is not suitable for long segment strictures as it has a higher recurrence rate and limited success in longer strictures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long urethral strictures require reconstructive surgery with techniques such as urethral repair using a buccal mucosal graft to provide a durable and effective solution for restoring normal urethral function.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a child who has asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis, lesions on the shaft of penis are as shown below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen nitidus

 

The image shows an aggregate of skin colored papules over the shaft of penis of a child which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

 

  • Lichen nitidus most frequently affects children or young adults.
  • The dorsum of the forearms or penis is where Lichen Nitidus most commonly manifests as tiny pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules. In early lesions, Lichen Nitidus and Lichen planus share a similar histological profile. Mucous membrane involvement is quite rare in lichen nitidus. True Koebner’s phenomenon is evident.
  • Lesions are self-limiting & no treatment is required.

 

 

Above Image depicts lichen nitidus over elbow with True Koebner’s phenomenon seen.

 

  • As both LP and Lichen Nitidus share a similar histological profile in early lesions, they are both regarded as variants of LP.
  • Claw clutching Ball appearance: The Ball is comprised of well circumscribed granulomatous infiltrate of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & occasional Langhan’s giant cells that are clutched by surrounding hyperplastic rete ridges, giving the overall claw clutching ball appearance.
  • Lesions are typically asymptomatic and infrequently need medical attention.
  • The histology of Lichen Nitidus is shown in the image below, where a well-defined granuloma is surrounded by rete pegs and appears to be claw clutching a ball.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus: This condition often presents as purplish, flat-topped bumps as shown in the image below, these lesions can be itchy. The lesions can also affect mucosal surfaces forming white lacy / reticulate pattern. The described presentation and the image provided do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Scrofuloderma: It is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis which results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from underlying tuberculous foci.

 

  • It typically presents as cold abscesses, ulcers, or nodules as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Scabies: This parasitic infection presents with intense itching.

 

  • The burrows of the mite may be seen on the skin, typically in the interdigital spaces.
  • The lesions in the image do not match the typical appearance of scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen nitidus is a probable diagnosis in a child with asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and genitalia, especially when the lesions appear as tiny, flesh-colored bumps.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 page no 37.3, 37.10, 37.11, 37.39

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition Page no 554

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is done for the treatment of Pilonidal sinus as shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transposition flap

 

The image provided shows a surgical procedure used to treat a pilonidal sinus. The procedure depicted is a Limberg flap, also known as a rhomboid flap. In this technique, a rhomboid-shaped piece of tissue adjacent to the excision site is cut and transposed to cover the wound created after the excision of the pilonidal sinus. This movement of tissue from the side to the gap is characteristic of a transposition flap. The Limberg flap is effective for ensuring tension-free closure and reducing the recurrence of the pilonidal sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial flap: This type of flap involves tissue that has a specific blood supply along its axis, which is not depicted in the image provided.

 

Option B. Rotation flap: A rotation flap involves rotating tissue around a pivot point to cover a defect. The image shows transposition rather than rotation.

 

Option C. Advancement flap: This involves moving tissue forward to cover a defect, typically in a straight line, which is not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Limberg flap, used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus, is a type of transposition flap where tissue from the adjacent side is cut, rotated, and used to close the defect created by the excision of the pilonidal sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: Identify the following image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Blister due to antemortem burns

 

The antemortem blister presents itself as an elevated dome, containing serous fluid enriched with proteins and chlorides. The surrounding base exhibits reddening and swollen papillae. In the case of antemortem burns, the adjacent skin displays heightened enzyme activity, particularly for sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers. This reaction is accompanied by increased levels of ATP, esterase’s, aminopeptidases, acid, and alkaline phosphatase. These vital reactions indicate notable cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, which are distinctive features of antemortem burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blister due to barbiturate poisoning: Barbiturate poisoning typically causes CNS depression, respiratory issues, and cardiovascular problems, not specific blister formation like burns.

 

Option C. Edema due to chemical burn: Chemical burns might cause edema, but the specific blister shown in the image is more characteristic of thermal burns.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid blisters and erosions rather than the tense blister shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem burn blisters are characterized by elevated domes filled with serous fluid, reddened surrounding base, and high enzyme activity, indicating significant cellular and tissue reactions distinct from other types of blisters or burns.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

 

The patient is diagnosed with mitral stenosis and has an irregularly irregular pulse, indicating atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is a common complication in patients with mitral stenosis and significantly increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Long-term anticoagulation therapy is essential in such patients to prevent these events. The presence of mitral stenosis, particularly moderate to severe, mandates the use of oral anticoagulants. Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant in this scenario because it is the only approved medication for patients with mitral stenosis and those with mechanical prosthetic heart valves.

 

Other anticoagulants, such as Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs), are not recommended in patients with valvular atrial fibrillation (AF associated with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves).

 

Additional Information –

 

CHA2DS2-VASc score to guide anticoagulation therapy in patients without mitral stenosis or a prosthetic valve.

 

  • C - Congestive heart failure: 1 point
  • H - Hypertension: 1 point
  • A - Age 65 to 74: 1 point, Age 75 and above: 2 points
  • D - Diabetes Mellitus: 1 point
  • S2 - Prior stroke or TIA: 2 points
  • Sex category (Female): 1 point
  • Vascular diseases (such as coronary artery disease or peripheral artery disease): 1 point

 

Scoring and Treatment Recommendations

 

  • Total Points: Ranges from 0 to 9.
  • Score of 2 or more: Strongly indicates the need for long-term anticoagulation (DOAC > warfarin).

 

Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Dabigatran, Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, or Edoxaban are preferred unless the patient has conditions like mitral stenosis or mechanical prosthetic valves, in which case Warfarin might be more appropriate.

 

  • Score less than 2: Anticoagulation may be considered but is less mandatory.

 

This scoring system is crucial for making informed decisions about anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, tailoring treatment based on individual risk profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a DOAC that is not recommended for patients with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves. It is suitable for non-valvular atrial fibrillation but not for valvular AF.

 

Option B. Aspirin 150mg: Aspirin is not sufficient as an anticoagulant in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially those with mitral stenosis. It does not provide the necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events in such high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Aspirin + Clopidogrel: This combination is also inadequate for anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation, particularly in patients with mitral stenosis. While it can prevent platelet aggregation, it does not provide the anticoagulation required to prevent thrombus formation in atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

choices.text: Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus
Superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus
Medial rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, superior rectus
Medial rectus, superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus

questions.text: What is the arrangement from near to far of the recti muscles attached towards the limbus? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cross-sectional view of the eye with the extraocular muscles labeled along with their distances of attachment from the limbus (sclerocorneal junction). The order of the recti muscles from closest to farthest attachment to the limbus is:

 

  • Medial rectus (5.5 mm)
  • Inferior rectus (6.5 mm)
  • Lateral rectus (6.9 mm)
  • Superior rectus (7.7 mm)

 

 

Remember :

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C and D are incorrect because they do not list the recti muscles in the correct order from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of the recti muscles from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus (sclerocorneal junction) is: medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, and superior rectus.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 with a previous cesarean section now presents at term. Which of the following is most favorable for a vaginal birth? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Previous lower segment cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

The type of uterine incision from a previous cesarean section significantly impacts the safety and likelihood of a successful vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC).

 

The lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) involves a transverse incision made in the lower, thinner part of the uterus. This type of incision is most favorable for a vaginal birth due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor, which is around 0.2%.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Incision Types and Associated Risks:

 

Option A. Previous upper segment cesarean: This is also known as a classical cesarean section, where the incision is made vertically in the thicker, upper part of the uterus. The risk of uterine rupture with this type of incision is significantly higher, ranging from 4-9%.

 

Option C. Previous J-shaped cesarean: This incision extends from the lower segment into the upper segment, increasing the risk of rupture to 4-9%.

 

Option D. Previous T-shaped cesarean: This incision combines a lower segment transverse incision with a vertical extension into the upper segment, also associated with a 4-9% risk of rupture.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most favorable incision for a vaginal birth after a previous cesarean section is the lower segment transverse incision due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor.

questions.text: All of the following are functions of the superior oblique except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

Explanation:

 

Adduction is not a function of the superior oblique muscle. Adduction involves moving the eyeball towards the midline (towards the nose), and this movement is primarily mediated by the medial rectus muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abduction: The superior oblique muscle helps in the lateral movement of the eyeball, meaning it moves the eye away from the midline (abduction).

 

Option C. Depression: When the eye is adducted (turned towards the nose), the superior oblique muscle helps to depress the eyeball, moving it downward.

 

Option D. Intorsion: This is the primary function of the superior oblique muscle. Intorsion involves the rotation of the top of the eyeball towards the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles and is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV). The primary functions of the superior oblique muscle can be remembered using the mnemonic "SO-LID":

 

  • Superior Oblique
  • Lateral movement (Abduction)
  • Intorsion
  • Depression

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via an increase in cAMP. The steps involved in this mechanism are given below. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Activation of PKA
  3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that act via an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) follow a specific sequence of events in the signal transduction pathway. The steps involved are as follows:

 

1. Activation of Adenylate Cyclase: Upon ligand binding to the G-stimulatory GPCR, the receptor activates adenylate cyclase.

 

3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP: The activated adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP).

 

2. Activation of Protein Kinase A (PKA): The increased levels of cAMP activate protein kinase A (PKA).

 

4. Phosphorylation of Target Proteins: PKA then phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to the desired cellular response.

 

This sequence of events accurately describes the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs is: Activation of adenylate cyclase, conversion of ATP to cAMP, activation of PKA, and phosphorylation of target proteins.

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: In which of the following is atropine contraindicated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute congestive glaucoma

 

The use of atropine is not recommended in cases of acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of increasing intraocular pressure.

 

  • Since atropine is a mydriatic, it may lead to the obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, causing a sudden increase in intraocular pressure.
  • Dim light can also precipitate an attack.
    • Atropine may be indicated as a cycloplegic agent to alleviate pain and prevent synechiae formation in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.
    • In malignant glaucoma, atropine can be the initial management option.
    • In corneal ulcers, atropine is used as an adjuvant therapy, to reduce pain induced by ciliary muscle spasm via its cycloplegic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute anterior uveitis: Atropine is actually beneficial in cases of acute anterior uveitis. It helps to relieve pain by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing the formation of posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and the lens), which can complicate uveitis.

 

Option C. Malignant glaucoma: In malignant glaucoma, atropine might be used as part of the management strategy to try to break the attack by deepening the anterior chamber and pulling the lens-iris diaphragm backward.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: Atropine is used in the treatment of corneal ulcers to provide comfort by relieving the painful ciliary spasm and to prevent synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine should be used cautiously, and is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma due to its potential to exacerbate the condition by further increasing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A patient had a cataract surgery 3 years back, now complains of decrease in vision and presented with the following slit lamp image. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior capsular opacification


Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is the most common complication occurring after cataract surgery. It is often referred to as an "after cataract" or "secondary cataract." PCO develops when lens epithelial cells remaining after surgery migrate and proliferate on the posterior capsule, which eventually leads to clouding.

 

The clinical presentation typically involves gradual vision loss without pain, as seen in this case. The slit lamp image provided shows an intraocular lens in place with opacification of the posterior capsule, which confirms the diagnosis of PCO.

 

The standard treatment for PCO is Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy, a simple and effective procedure to restore vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakic Bullous Keratopathy: This condition occurs due to endothelial cell loss following cataract surgery, leading to corneal decompensation and formation of painful bullae on the corneal surface. It presents with pain and redness in the eye, which is not observed in this patient.

 

 

Option C. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophy is a genetic disorder that usually presents bilaterally and is unrelated to cataract surgery. It does not cause symptoms similar to those seen in this case and would not present specifically in one eye following cataract surgery.

 

 

Option D. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract: This type of cataract develops in the back of the lens before surgery and is not seen after cataract surgery. Once removed during cataract surgery, posterior subcapsular cataracts do not recur.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication after cataract surgery, presenting with gradual vision loss without pain. It is treated with ND laser capsulotomy.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefotetan

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex is known for its intrinsic resistance to various antimicrobial agents, including cefotetan.

 

B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to:

 

  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymixin
  • First and second-generation cephalosporins
  • Carboxypenicillins

 

B. Cepacia can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include:

 

  • Meropenem
  • Ceftazidime
  • Piperacillin
  • Temocillin
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ceftazidime: Incorrect because ceftazidime is actually among the antimicrobials that are effective against B. cepacia complex, suggesting it can bypass the bacterium’s resistance mechanisms.

 

Option B. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Incorrect, as this combination is also effective against B. cepacia, demonstrating its capability to treat infections caused by this pathogen.

 

Option C. Temocillin: Incorrect, as temocillin is listed as effective against B. cepacia complex, indicating its efficacy in combating this resistant bacterium.

 

Educational Objective

 

Burkholderia cepacia exhibits resistance to several antibiotic classes, including second-generation cephalosporins like cefotetan.

questions.text: A woman at 8 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propylthiouracil

 

During the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism. This preference is due to the fact that PTU has a lower risk of causing birth defects compared to Methimazole, which is associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis (a congenital skin defect). PTU is considered safer in early pregnancy, especially during organogenesis (the first trimester), as it crosses the placenta less readily than Methimazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Methimazole is typically avoided during the first trimester because it is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly the risk of aplasia cutis and other congenital abnormalities.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is a prodrug that is converted to Methimazole in the body. Like Methimazole, it is also avoided during the first trimester due to the risk of congenital defects.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnancy at any stage, as it can destroy fetal thyroid tissue, leading to permanent hypothyroidism in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism due to its lower risk of causing birth defects compared to other antithyroid medications.

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: Which of the following is a manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bitot's spots

 

Bitot's spots are a characteristic manifestation of vitamin A deficiency. These are foamy, triangular, silvery-white spots that appear on the conjunctiva, typically on the temporal side of the cornea. They are composed of keratin debris and are a sign of xerophthalmia (dry eye) associated with vitamin A deficiency. Bitot's spots are an important clinical sign used to diagnose vitamin A deficiency, especially in developing countries where this nutritional deficiency is more common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's striae: Incorrect. These are vertical lines seen in the cornea of patients with keratoconus, a progressive eye disease that causes thinning and bulging of the cornea. They are not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Arlt's line: Incorrect. This refers to a linear scar on the inner surface of the upper eyelid, typically seen in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It is not associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option D. Horner tantra dots: Incorrect. This appears to be a misspelling of "Horner-Trantas dots," which are white, chalky accumulations of eosinophils and epithelial cells at the limbus (the border between the cornea and the sclera). They are commonly seen in patients with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, an allergic eye condition, and are not related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot's spots are a characteristic ocular manifestation of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as foamy, silvery-white spots on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

Explanation:

 

  • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. 
  • It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-Control Study: This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.

 

Option C. Ecological Study: These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.

 

Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and bleeding. After diagnosis, it is determined to be inverted papilloma. What is the correct description of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benign and locally invasive

 

Inverted papilloma, also known as Schneiderian papilloma or Transitional cell papilloma, is characterized by its benign nature but with a propensity for local invasiveness. This type of tumor arises from the epithelial lining of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses and is notable for its tendency to grow inward into the underlying stroma rather than outward.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D. Malignant/Malignant and locally invasive: These are incorrect as inverted papilloma is primarily benign, though it requires aggressive management due to its invasive nature.

 

Option C. Benign and non-invasive: This is incorrect because, although benign, inverted papillomas are distinctly characterized by their local invasiveness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor primarily affecting the nasal cavity, requiring aggressive surgical management due to its invasive characteristics and potential complications. Regular follow-up is crucial due to the risk of recurrence and rare malignant transformation.

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Man acts as the reservoir

 

Humans are the dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis virus.

 

Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which belongs to the Flavivirus family.

 

Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis can range from mild, flu-like illness to severe neurological complications, such as high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, seizures, paralysis, and even coma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The disease is transmitted by Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

 

Option B. Herons act as reservoir hosts and pigs as amplifier hosts.

 

Option D. The control measures include mosquito control, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings and vaccinating pigs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the transmission dynamics of Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective control measures. While humans can become severely ill from JE, they do not play a significant role in the disease's transmission cycle, emphasizing the importance of controlling mosquito populations and managing amplifier hosts like pigs to reduce the incidence of this potentially deadly disease.

choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: A patient came to emergency with severe breathlessness. CXR is taken and shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pleural effusion

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray (CXR) of the patient shows a whiteout on one side with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side. These findings are indicative of a massive pleural effusion.

 

Pleural effusion: This condition results in the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, leading to lung compression and a shift of the mediastinum, including the trachea, away from the affected side. The presence of a large whiteout on the X-ray, along with the tracheal deviation to the opposite side, strongly suggests pleural effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: This condition would typically present with a hyperlucent (dark) area on the X-ray without lung markings, rather than a whiteout. It also generally causes a tracheal shift towards the opposite side, but the appearance on the X-ray would be different.

 

Option B. Consolidation: This condition involves filling of the alveoli with fluid or other material, leading to a whiteout appearance on the X-ray. However, it does not usually cause a significant tracheal shift.

 

Option C. Collapse: This condition, also known as atelectasis, would cause a shift of the trachea towards the affected side. It can present with a whiteout on the X-ray, but the tracheal deviation would be opposite to that seen in pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A massive pleural effusion is characterized by a whiteout on the chest X-ray with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side.

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: Identify the stage of the pressure sore:  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

A stage 4 pressure sore is characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. The image shows a deep ulcer with visible bone and extensive tissue damage, which are hallmarks of a stage 4 pressure sore. This stage represents the most severe form of pressure ulcer, with significant risk for infection and complications due to the depth of tissue involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: This stage involves non-blanching erythema of intact skin. It is the earliest stage of pressure ulceration, where the skin appears red and does not turn white when pressed.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 pressure sores involve partial-thickness skin loss with exposure of the dermis. They may appear as shallow, open ulcers with a red or pink wound bed, without slough or deeper tissue exposure.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 sores show full-thickness skin loss, where subcutaneous fat may be visible but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed. The ulcer may include undermining and tunneling but does not extend into deeper structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 4 pressure sores are the most advanced, involving full-thickness tissue loss with visible bone, muscle, or tendon. Early identification and treatment of pressure sores can prevent progression to this severe stage.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical wall repair 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital condition where the baby is born with the intestines located outside of the body through an opening in the abdominal wall. 

 

This is the most appropriate management strategy. It involves surgical correction where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdominal cavity and the abdominal wall defect is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This is not an appropriate strategy for gastroschisis. Without prompt surgical intervention, the exposed intestines are at risk of infection, dehydration, and injury.

 

Option C. Slowly putting it inside: While the concept of gradually reducing the bowel back into the abdominal cavity (sometimes called "silo" reduction) is a valid approach, it is performed as part of the surgical management and under controlled conditions, not as a standalone treatment.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This option is not relevant to the management of gastroschisis. There is no need to excise the bowel unless there is nonviable tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management for a neonate with gastroschisis is immediate surgical repair to return the intestines to the abdominal cavity and close the defect in the abdominal wall.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are false about IL-12 except? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases production of interferon- γ
  2. Inhibits T cells
  3. Inhibits B cells
  4. Produced by macrophages
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is a cytokine produced primarily by antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells. It plays a critical role in the immune response by promoting the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells, which are essential for cell-mediated immunity.

 

1. Increases production of interferon-γ (IFN-γ): IL-12 stimulates T cells and natural killer (NK) cells to produce IFN-γ, a cytokine crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

4. Produced by macrophages: IL-12 is indeed produced by macrophages, along with other antigen-presenting cells, in response to pathogens.

 

Other options:

 

2. Inhibits T cells: This is incorrect. IL-12 actually activates T cells, particularly promoting the differentiation into Th1 cells, rather than inhibiting them.

 

3. Inhibits B cells: This is also incorrect. IL-12 does not inhibit B cells; instead, it indirectly influences B cell function by promoting a Th1 response, which supports cellular immunity over humoral (B cell) immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).
